original_data.question: Two weeks after starting chemotherapy with etoposide, a 66-year-old man with small cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of persistent nausea and vomiting. His symptoms improve significantly after the administration of metoclopramide. This patient's symptoms were most likely due to the effect of chemotherapy on which of the following structures?

model_response:
The area postrema is located on the dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata, and it is a pa of the chemoreceptor trigger zone. The area postrema is a pa of the brain that is not protected by the blood-brain barrier. It is a pa of the vomiting center, and it is stimulated by emetic substances that are present in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid. The vestibular nerve is a pa of the auditory and vestibular system and is not directly involved in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Intestinal smooth muscle is not directly involved in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. The vagus nerve is involved in the parasympathetic control of the stomach and upper intestine and is not directly involved in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Any period of seven consecutive days.
The use of DRUGS to treat a DISEASE or its symptoms. One example is the use of ANTINEOPLASTIC AGENTS to treat CANCER.

A semisynthetic derivative of PODOPHYLLOTOXIN that exhibits antitumor activity. Etoposide inhibits DNA synthesis by forming a complex with topoisomerase II and DNA. This complex induces breaks in double stranded DNA and prevents repair by topoisomerase II binding. Accumulated breaks in DNA prevent entry into the mitotic phase of cell division, and lead to cell death. Etoposide acts primarily in the G2 and S phases of the cell cycle.
Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

An anaplastic, highly malignant, and usually bronchogenic carcinoma composed of small ovoid cells with scanty neoplasm. It is characterized by a dominant, deeply basophilic nucleus, and absent or indistinct nucleoli. (From Stedman, 25th ed; Holland et al., Cancer Medicine, 3d ed, p1286-7)
Having a black or dark core or plug.

An unpleasant sensation in the stomach usually accompanied by the urge to vomit. Common causes are early pregnancy, sea and motion sickness, emotional stress, intense pain, food poisoning, and various enteroviruses.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.
Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
A dopamine D2 antagonist that is used as an antiemetic.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.
The use of DRUGS to treat a DISEASE or its symptoms. One example is the use of ANTINEOPLASTIC AGENTS to treat CANCER.
The components and their relationship and manner of arrangement in constituting a whole.
